div1.p: This article, originally published in "Horizontes Medicos," describes the history of Camp Lazear and the confirmation of Finlay's mosquito theory. The translation was made by Moran.

div1.head: Translation [from Spanish] of Forgotten Corner (Rincon Olvidado), [June 1944]
div1.p:
In a corner of the unsightly district of “Pogolotti”, at the foot of an
abandoned quarry, there stands almost in ruins, due to the action of time, the last
vestige of what in a distant epoch was a hospital or more correctly speaking what was
called “Camp Lazear” where were carried out certain experiments of the most important
realized in the field of medicine: the confirmation of the theories of our great Carlos
Finlay about the transmission of yellow fever by the culex mosquito.

To carry out such experiments there were constructed two small wooden shacks,
14 x 20 feet, with two windows, respectively. The first was designated “Building No. 1”
or “The Infected Clothing Building.”

In this building, where were accumulated clothing used by the victims of the
disease, there slept for many days (nights) Dr. Robert Cooke and six other volunteers,
doing so on pillows contaminated with blood and vomit of yellow fever patients. None
of the volunteers contracted the disease, hence the Sanarelli theory which affirmed
that yellow fever was transmitted by “fomes” was discarded.

The second, designated “Building No. 2” or “Infected Mosquito Building” was
divided in two parts, separated by a fine-meshed wire screen. On one side reclined Mr.
John Moran with his body exposed to the bites of fifteen mosquitos which were set free
in the room. The stay there of Mr. Moran, a little more than an hour, resulted in his
contracting the disease, while other volunteers who remained several hours on the other
side of the metallic curtain, where there were no mosquitos, remained healthy.

Following these incontrovertible proofs more were realized in which American
and Spanish volunteers submitted themselves, on the termination of which Camp Lazear
was abandoned, leading to a start in 1901 by General Gorgas of his famous campaign of
sanitation, the fruits of which became evident with the disappearance from our land of
yellow fever and rendering possible the hitherto impossible task of building the
Panama Canal.

Today, we take pleasure in presenting a photograph of “Building No. 1”, which
may be the last since the abandoned state of same tends to deteriorate more each day
its dilapidated walls. Since our visit last year the porch has disappeared and it seems
2.
that this destruction runs on a par with our forgetfulness of those things of historic
and scientific value which should be preserved for the glory of our illustrious country-
men who gave lustre to our country with the guerdon of their wisdom and good works.

The distinguished North American doctor, Phil S. Hench, enthusiastic admirer
of Finley's work, discovered this building in 1941 and thanks to his generosity, certain
small reparations were made to same although upon destroying the porch, the person in
whose charge the repairs were made changed somewhat the original aspect of “Building
No. 1” of Camp Lazear.

In another of the photographs we present can be seen Mr. John Moran, one of
the survivors of that notable episode, who has lived amongst us since that memorable
day and who so kindly furnished the data which has served us as a basis for this brief
review.

As the Colonel is well aware, “Building No. 1” did not originally have a
porch. It had a narrow vestibule which must have disappeared years ago. An effort
was made to repair the narrow porch, none the less, but the supports and boards had
rotted so much that, short of employing new lumber, it was considered the better part
of wisdom to remove it altogether rather than to have it collapse and injure one of
the occupants when and as it might give way. With its destruction no part of the
original building was involved.
